questions.title: Passage Ⅰ
questions.article:
In 3 studies, students found the rate, R, at which water flowed through each of several holes in a water-filled cylinder. They also measured the horizontal distance, L, spanned by each stream of water (see Figure 1).


The students tested 3 cylinders, X, Y, and Z, each having the same diameter and height. Each cylinder had a hole at each of 5 depths, D, measured from the top of the cylinder. All of the holes in a given cylinder had the same cross-sectional area, A. Holes other than the one being tested were covered with tape.

In each trial, R and L were determined for one value of D. Throughout each trial, a student kept the cylinder being tested filled to the brim with water. Another student positioned a beaker to capture the stream of water. Using a stopwatch, the students measured the time, t, in seconds (sec), required for 100 cm3 of water to accumulate in the beaker. Using the formula R = 100 cm3 ÷ t sec, they calculated R in cm3/sec. Finally, using a tape measure, they found L in cm.

Study 1
Using Cylinder X, the students found R and L for each D. The cross-sectional area A of each hole in Cylinder X equaled 0.0100 cm2 (see Table 1).


Study 2
Using Cylinder Y, the students found R and L for each D. The area A of each hole in Cylinder Y equaled 0.0200cm2 (see Table 2).


Study 2
Using Cylinder Z, the students found R and L for each D. The area A of each hole in Cylinder Z equaled 0.0300 cm2 (see Table 3).
questions.question: 1.  Which of the following graphs best represents how L varied with D in Trials 1-5?

questions.question: 5.  Suppose, at the beginning of a trial, a student had filled a cylinder to the brim with water, but, as the trial proceeded, the student had not added any more water to the cylinder. As the trial proceeded, R most likely would have:

choices.A: increased, because the water pressure at the hole being tested would have increased.
choices.B: increased, because the water pressure at the hole being tested would have decreased.
choices.C: decreased, because the water pressure at the hole being tested would have increased.
choices.D: decreased, because the water pressure at the hole being tested would have decreased.

questions.question: 6.  Based on the results of the 3 studies, for a given D, did L depend on A ?

choices.A: Yes, because as A increased, L increased.
choices.B: Yes, because as A increased, L remained constant.
choices.C: No, because as A increased, L increased.
choices.D: No, because as A increased, L remained constant.

questions.title: Passage Ⅱ
questions.article:
Asemichthys taylori is a predatory saltwater fish that sometimes uses its teeth to punch holes in the shells of its prey, which are ingested (eaten) shell and all. Scientists collected 176 A. taylori and placed them in a holding tank. All shells from the fecal waste of the A. taylori were collected for the next 48 hr. Table 1 shows the number of shells ingested by the A. taylori, the number of survivors (ingested shells that contained living, undigested organisms), and the percent of shells with punched holes for 3 main groups of prey: gastropods, bivalves, and hermit crabs. Table 2 shows the same information for 4 types of gastropods.



Tables adapted from Stephen F. Norton, “Role of the Gastropod Shell and Operculum in Inhibiting Predation by Fishes." ©1988 by the American Association for the Advancement of Science.
questions.question: 7. According to Table 2, the highest percent of shells was punched for which type of gastropod?

questions.question: 8.  Which of the following lists the gastropods from Table 2 in order from the greatest number ingested to the smallest number ingested?

questions.question: 9.  The scientists hypothesized that A. taylori would not punch holes in the shells of prey if digestion was possible without punching. Are the data for any of the gastropods listed in Table 2 consistent with this hypothesis?

choices.A: Yes; none of the limpet shells were punched, and none of the ingested limpets survived.
choices.B: Yes; 79.2% of Alvinia shells were punched, and some of the ingested Alvinia survived.
choices.C: No; none of the limpet shells were punched, and none of the ingested limpets survived.
choices.D: No; 79.2% of Alvinia shells were punched, and none of the ingested Alvinia survived.

questions.question: 10.  Which of the following statements concerning hermit crabs is most consistent with Table 1 ?

choices.A: A. taylori punch the shells of most hermit crabs that are eaten, but the hermit crabs usually survive ingestion.
choices.B: A. taylori punch the shells of most hermit crabs that are eaten, and the hermit crabs are usually digested.
choices.C: A. taylori do NOT punch the shells of most hermit crabs that are eaten, and the hermit crabs usually survive ingestion.
choices.D: A. taylori do NOT punch the shells of most hermit crabs that are eaten, and the hermit crabs are usually digested.

Table 1 shows the number of shells ingested by the A. taylori, the number of survivors (ingested shells that contained living, undigested organisms), and the percent of shells with punched holes for 3 main groups of prey: gastropods, bivalves, and hermit crabs. questions.question: 11.  Based on Table 2, is it possible that all of the Alvinia with unpunched shells survived ingestion?

choices.A: Yes, because approximately 20% of Alvinia shells were unpunched, and approximately 20% of ingested Alvinia survived.
choices.B: Yes, because approximately 10% of Alvinia shells were unpunched, and approximately 20% of ingested Alvinia survived.
choices.C: No, because approximately 20% of Alvinia shells were unpunched, and approximately 10% of ingested Alvinia survived.
choices.D: No, because approximately 80% of Alvinia shells were unpunched, and approximately 20% of ingested Alvinia survived.

questions.title: Passage Ⅲ
questions.article:
The chemical equations in Figure 1 show what occurs when 1 formula unit of each of 3 salts dissolves in H2O.


The conductivity of a solution is a measure of its ability to conduct electricity. Figure 2 shows how the conductivity (in millisiemens per centimeter, mS/cm) of an 18°C aqueous solution of each of the 3 salts varies with concentration. Concentration is measured as millimoles of salt per liter of solution (mmol/L). A millimole is 6 x 1020 formula units of any salt.


Figure 2 adapted from John A. Dean, Lange's Handbook of Chemistry. @1992 by McGraw-Hill, lnc.

Figure 3 shows how the conductivity of an aqueous NaCl solution at 4 temperatures with concentration (measured as % NaCl by mass).
questions.question: 12. At aqueous Na2SO4 solution at 18°C has a conductivity of 12 mS/cm. According to Figure 2, the Na2SO4 concentration of this solution is closest to which of the following?

questions.question: 16.  According to Figure 3, which of the following NaCl solutions would have a conductivity of 200 mS/cm at 100℃?

choices.A: 5 g of NaCl dissolved in 20 g of H2O

questions.title: Passage Ⅳ
questions.article:
Two types of friction affecting bicycle riders are:

· air resistance

· rolling resistance between the tires and the ground

Table 1 gives the air resistance, RA, affecting a rider moving at speed V when the cross-sectional area of the rider plus bicycle equaled X. Table 1 also gives the power, PA, in watts (W), the rider had to generate to compensate for RA to maintain V. Figure 1 gives the power, PA + R, in horsepower (hp), a rider had to generate to compensate for RA plus rolling resistance to maintain V = 5.6 m/sec or 11. 2 m/sec for a wheel diameter of 16 inches or 27 inches and various tire pressures. Figure 2 is a graph of power in W versus power in hp.



Figure 1 adapted from Frank Roland Whitt and David Gordon Wilson, "Bicycling Science." @1974 by The Massachusetts institute of Technology.

questions.question: 21.  A student suggested that for the rider to maintain a speed of 11. 2 m/sec on a bicycle with 27 inch wheels, PA+R would be less if the tire pressure were 80 1b/in than if the tire pressure were 140 1b/in2. Does Figure 1 support the student's suggestion?

choices.A: Yes; according to Figure 1, as tire pressure increased, PA+R increased.
choices.B: Yes; according to Figure 1, as tire pressure increased, PA+R decreased.
choices.C: No; according to Figure 1, as tire pressure increased, PA+R increased.
choices.D: No; according to Figure 1, as tire pressure increased, PA+R decreased.

questions.title: Passage Ⅴ
questions.article:
A solution containing neutral red (an acid-base indicator) is yellow if the pH is greater than 8.0 or red if the pH is less than 6.8. In solution, a neutral red molecule is either uncharged (NR) or charged (NRH+). The color of a neutral red solution depends on the NR and NRH+ concentrations (see Figure 1).



A colored component of a solution will strongly absorb visible light over a certain range of wavelengths (measured in nanometers, nm). At any wavelength in that range, the concentration of the component will be directly proportional to the solution's absorbance. Absorbance is measured by using a spectrophotometer. In a spectrophotometer, a certain wavelength of light is directed through a sample of the solution onto a detector that determines what fraction of the light is absorbed by the solution.

Experiment 1
Two 1. 00 L buffer solutions (solutions that maintain a constant pH) that were pH = 3.0 and pH = 9.0, respectively, were prepared. Then, 15.00 mg of neutral red was added to each solution. At pH = 3.0, virtually all neutral red molecules are charged. At pH = 9.0, virtually all neutral red molecules are uncharged. Next, 5.00 mL of the pH = 3.0 solution was added to a cuvette (a transparent container). The cuvette was placed in the spectrophotometer. The absorbance over the visible spectrum was measured. The procedure was repeated with the pH = 9. 0 buffer solution (see Figure 2) .


Experiment 2
The procedure in Experiment 1 was used to study neutral red at 5 other pHs (see Figure 3).



(Note: Without neutral red present, the buffer solutions used in Experiments 1 and 2 do not measurably absorb visible light.)

Figures 2 and 3 adapted from Krystin P. Alter, John L. Molloy, and Emily D. Niemeyer, "Spectrophotometric Determination of the Dissociation Constant of an Acid-Base Indicator Using a Mathematical Deconvolution Technique." ©2005 by Division of Chemical Education, Inc., American Chemical Society.
questions.question: 22. Based on the results of Experiment 1, from 375 nm to 625 nm, how does the absorbance of a neutral red solution at pH = 9.0 vary with wavelength? The absorbance:

Figures 2 and 3 adapted from Krystin P. Alter, John L. Molloy, and Emily D. Niemeyer, "Spectrophotometric Determination of the Dissociation Constant of an Acid-Base Indicator Using a Mathematical Deconvolution Technique." ©2005 by Division of Chemical Education, Inc., American Chemical Society.
questions.question: 23.  Suppose an additional trial had been done in Experiment 2 at pH=7. 25. The absorbance of the solution at 525 nm would most likely have been:

questions.title: Passage Ⅴ
questions.article:
A solution containing neutral red (an acid-base indicator) is yellow if the pH is greater than 8.0 or red if the pH is less than 6.8. In solution, a neutral red molecule is either uncharged (NR) or charged (NRH+). The color of a neutral red solution depends on the NR and NRH+ concentrations (see Figure 1).



A colored component of a solution will strongly absorb visible light over a certain range of wavelengths (measured in nanometers, nm). At any wavelength in that range, the concentration of the component will be directly proportional to the solution's absorbance. Absorbance is measured by using a spectrophotometer. In a spectrophotometer, a certain wavelength of light is directed through a sample of the solution onto a detector that determines what fraction of the light is absorbed by the solution.

Experiment 1
Two 1. 00 L buffer solutions (solutions that maintain a constant pH) that were pH = 3.0 and pH = 9.0, respectively, were prepared. Then, 15.00 mg of neutral red was added to each solution. At pH = 3.0, virtually all neutral red molecules are charged. At pH = 9.0, virtually all neutral red molecules are uncharged. Next, 5.00 mL of the pH = 3.0 solution was added to a cuvette (a transparent container). The cuvette was placed in the spectrophotometer. The absorbance over the visible spectrum was measured. The procedure was repeated with the pH = 9. 0 buffer solution (see Figure 2) .


Experiment 2
The procedure in Experiment 1 was used to study neutral red at 5 other pHs (see Figure 3).



(Note: Without neutral red present, the buffer solutions used in Experiments 1 and 2 do not measurably absorb visible light.)

Figures 2 and 3 adapted from Krystin P. Alter, John L. Molloy, and Emily D. Niemeyer, "Spectrophotometric Determination of the Dissociation Constant of an Acid-Base Indicator Using a Mathematical Deconvolution Technique." ©2005 by Division of Chemical Education, Inc., American Chemical Society.
questions.question: 24.  Which of the following best describes the solutions that were measured using the spectrophotomețer in Experiments 1 and 2 ? In Experiment 1:

choices.A: one buffer solution was measured at two different pHs; in Experiment 2, one buffer solution was measured at five different pHs.
choices.B: one buffer solution was measured at five different pHs; in Experiment 2, one buffer solution was measured at two different pHs.
choices.C: two buffer solutions of different pH were measured; in Experiment 2, five buffer solutions of different pH were measured.
choices.D: five buffer solutions of different pH were measured; in Experiment 2, two buffer solutions of different pH were measured.

questions.question: 25.  Solution A contains neutral red and is red. Solution B is colorless. Solution B is added to Solution A, and the resulting solution is yellow. Is Solution A acidic or basic, and is Solution B acidic or basic?

choices.A: Solution A: acidic               Solution B: basic
choices.B: Solution A: basic               Solution B: acidic
choices.C: Solution A: acidic               Solution B: acidic
choices.D: Solution A: basic               Solution B: basic

questions.question: 26.  In Experiment 2, at 525 nm, compared to the absorbance of the pH = 6. 0 solution, the absorbance of the pH = 7. 0 solution was:

choices.A: higher, because it had the higher NRH+ concentration.
choices.B: lower, because it had the lower NRH+ concentration.

questions.question: 27.  In Experiment 1, the solution of neutral red at pH=9.0 was:

choices.A: yellow, because virtually all neutral red molecules were charged.
choices.B: yellow, because virtually all neutral red molecules were uncharged.
choices.C: red, because virtually all neutral red molecules were charged.
choices.D: red, because virtually all neutral red molecules were uncharged.

questions.title: Passage Ⅵ
questions.article:
Three studies examined the effects of adding fly ash (fine-grained ash from burning coal) to a sandy soil. In the studies, 4 samples were analyzed: Sample 1 was pure sandy soil, Samples 2 and 3 each had a different amount of fly ash thoroughly mixed with sandy soil, and Sample 4 was pure fly ash.

Study 1
To determine the relative water-holding capacity of the 4 samples, the percent by mass of sand-size, silt-size, and clay-size particles in each sample was measured (see Table 1) . As the total percent by mass of silt-size and clay-size particles in a sample increases, the water-holding capacity of the sample increases.


Study 2
Sample 1 was analyzed for boron (B), an element that inhibits plant growth. Next, 4 kg of Sample 1 was placed in each of 3 identical pots. Eight corn seeds were planted in each pot. Identical amounts of water were added to the pots regularly. Fifty-five days after planting, the corn plants in each pot were harvested, dried completely, and weighed. These procedures were repeated with Samples 2 and 3 (see Table 2) .


Study 3
Equal-volume portions of Samples 1-3 were leached by running an amount of water equivalent to 100 cm of rainfall through them to reduce the B content. (The B compounds that were present are water-soluble.) Then, all the procedures of Study 2 were repeated with those leached portions (see Table 3).


Tables adapted from M. Ghodrati et al., “Enhancing the Benefits of Fly Ash as a Soil Amendment by Pre-Leaching." ©1995 by Williams and Wilkins.
questions.question: 28. In Study 3, from sample to sample, as the percent by mass of fly ash increased, the plant dry mass:

questions.title: Passage Ⅶ
questions.article:
Figure 1 depicts meiosis. Meiosis consists of 2 cell divisions, Meiosis I and Meiosis II. During Meiosis I, 1 cell (Cell A) divides into 2 new cells (Cells AA and AB). Then each new cell divides during Meiosis II.



A cell entering meiosis contains 2N chromosomes (N homologous pairs). After meiosis, the number of chromosomes in each cell is N. Table 1 lists N and 2N for various animals.


Two types of chromosomes are shown in Figure 2: chromosomes that contain 2 double-stranded DNA (dsDNA) molecules (referred to here as double chromosomes) and chromosomes that contain 1 dsDNA molecule (referred to here as single chromosomes). When 1 double chromosome splits, 2 single chromosomes are formed.

Figure 2 also shows that as a result of meiosis, each of the 4 cells produced during Meiosis II contains 1 of the single chromosomes from each homologous pair of double chromosomes. (The cells depicted in Figure 2 represent cells from an organism that has 1 pair of homologous chromosomes.)


Two students present opposing models predicting when each double chromosome splits during meiosis.

Student 1
During Meiosis I, the 2 double chromosomes from each homologous pair segregate into different cells. During Meiosis II, each double chromosome splits into 2 single chromosomes, which then segregate into different cells (see Figure 3).



Student 2
During Meiosis I, each double chromosome splits into 2 single chromosomes, which then segregate into different cells. During Meiosis II, in each cell, the 2 single chromosomes from each homologous pair segregate into different cells (see Figure 4).
questions.question: 34. A cell from 1 of the animals listed in Table 1 was isolated. The cell underwent meiosis. After completing meiosis, each of the new cells produced during Meiosis II contained 32 chromosomes. This ceil most likely came from which animal?

questions.question: 35.  Based on Student l's model, if a cell enters meiosis with 4 double chromosomes, each of the 2 new cells produced during Meiosis I will have how many double chromosomes before these cells enter Meiosis II ?

questions.question: 36.  If 1 cell is placed in a test tube and the cell then under-goes meiosis, how many cells will be contained in the test tube immediately following the completion of meiosis?
